straph.streaming_algorithms.fastest_path_algorithm.remove_dominated_elements(M, v)[source]¶
straph.streaming_algorithms.fastest_path_algorithm.unpack_ttr(L, index_node_to_scc, dict_comp_to_ttr, done)[source]¶
straph.streaming_algorithms.fastest_path_algorithm.update_paths(M, t0, t1, u, v)[source]¶

Update L structure Elements of L are sorted by their starting time, (and the better the duration is the worse the arrival time is). We just need to add to L[v] the last element in L[u] before the beginning of the link (t0) and every other element during the link (from t0 to t1). :param M: :param t0: :param t1: :param u: :param v: :return:

straph.streaming_algorithms.kcores_streaming module¶

straph.streaming_algorithms.kcores_streaming.KC_list(k, a_l, node_label, C=[], R=[], DEBUG=None)[source]¶

Compute k_cliques of a static graph from its core odering dag. :param k: The parameter k, number of nodes in the considered cliques :param a_l: Adjacency list of the core ordering dag :param node_label: label of each node :param C: List of current cliques :param R: List of completed cliques :param DEBUG: :return: The k_cliques of the graph. References ——— [2] Listing k-cliques in Sparse Real-World Graphs Maximilien Danisch, et al., 2018 https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3186125

straph.streaming_algorithms.kcores_streaming.algo_kcores_batagelj(a_l, degrees, core_ordering=False)[source]¶

Compute k_cores of a static graph from its adjacency list and nodes degrees :return: the core number of each node in the graph References ———- [1] An O(m) Algorithm for Cores Decomposition of Networks Vladimir Batagelj and Matjaz Zaversnik, 2003. http://arxiv.org/abs/cs.DS/0310049

straph.streaming_algorithms.shortest_path_streaming.bfs(N, source, destinations)[source]¶
straph.streaming_algorithms.shortest_path_streaming.compute_FSP_in_wcc(source, N, D, A, P)[source]¶

One pass algorithm to compute single source distances inside a WCC BFS like (to respect the temporal order of the links). We can visit each node several time, but we visit links only once !! :param source: :param links: :param D: Containing the distances to each node from the source. :param A: containing the best duration for a shortest path. (fastest shortest path). :param P: Containing the current marked out shortest path. :return:

straph.streaming_algorithms.shortest_path_streaming.unpack_path(p, a, l, source, destination)[source]¶

Backtracking procedure in order to keep the coherency of the path. :param p: precedent node in the path :param a: arrival time in n :param l: leaving time of n :param source: :param destination: :return:

straph.streaming_algorithms.shortest_path_streaming.update_FSP(L, t0, t1, u, v)[source]¶

FSP : Fastest Shortest Path Update L structure Elements of L are sorted by their distances, (and the better the distance is the worse the arrival time is). We just need to add to L[v] the last element in L[u] before the beginning of the link (t0) and every other element during the link (from t0 to t1). :param L: :param t0: :param t1: :param u: :param v: :return:

Update L structure Elements of L are sorted by their distances, (and the better the distance is the worse the arrival time is). We just need to add to L[v] the last element in L[u] before the beginning of the link (t0) and every other element during the link (from t0 to t1). :param L: :param t0: :param t1: :param u: :param v: :return:
